item.title: U.S. and China to Hold First Trade Talks Since Trump’s Tariffs
item.description: Scott Bessent, the Treasury secretary, and Jamieson Greer, the United States trade representative, will discuss trade and economic matters with the officials this week.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson

item.title: GM Cuts Profit Forecast by 20% and Says Auto Tariffs Will Cost It Billions
item.description: General Motors now expects to earn a lot less than it did before President Trump imposed 25 percent tariffs on imported cars and auto parts.
item.dc:creator: Neal E. Boudette

item.title: Ford Says Tariffs Will Cost Company $1.5 Billion in 2025
item.description: Ford Motor also reported a sharp drop in profits in the first three months of the year.
item.dc:creator: Neal E. Boudette

item.title: Scott Bessent Urges Investors to Bet on Trump’s Economic Plan
item.description: The Treasury secretary urged executives and entrepreneurs to look beyond the Trump administration’s trade agenda.
item.dc:creator: Alan Rappeport

item.title: Would the Housing Crisis Ease if Boomers Rented Out Their Empty Rooms?
item.description: Millions of single-family homes are underused, on spacious lots. Refitting them for “roommate houses” or backyard cottages could make a difference.
item.dc:creator: Conor Dougherty

item.title: ‘People Who Are Salaried Are Crying’: Taxes on Workers Add to Debt Misery
item.description: Increased payroll taxes are one element of a desperate bid in Kenya to keep the government running and pay off the country’s foreign creditors.
item.dc:creator: Patricia Cohen

item.title: Oil Prices Are Falling. Here’s Where That Could Spell Trouble.
item.description: For countries that depend heavily on oil revenue, dropping prices are worrisome.
item.dc:creator: Neil MacFarquhar

item.title: A Tidal Wave of Change Is Headed for the U.S. Economy
item.description: American consumers are not yet seeing much evidence of the drastic changes President Trump has made on trade. But they are on their way.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson

item.title: Trump Ends Chinese Tariff Loophole, Raising the Cost of Online Goods
item.description: Supporters say the change is important to stop cheap Chinese goods from entering the U.S. But the decision could drive up prices for goods Americans buy online.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson

item.title: U.S. and China Dig In on Trade War, With No Plans for Formal Talks
item.description: The standoff over terms of negotiations, and whether they are happening, signals that a protracted economic fight lies ahead.
item.dc:creator: Alan Rappeport

item.title: Here’s What 7 Americans Think of Trump’s First 100 Days
item.description: Here’s what a variety of voters who made their choices in November’s election with some hesitation had to say about President Trump’s first 100 days.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: Trump, on Tariffs, Says ‘Maybe the Children Will Have 2 Dolls Instead of 30’
item.description: At the end of a cabinet meeting, the president allowed for the possibility that trade war could disrupt supply chains.
item.dc:creator: Shawn McCreesh

item.title: Trump Signs Executive Order Walking Back Some Auto Tariffs
item.description: Most levies on imported cars and car parts will remain in place, but automakers have secured some relaxation of the trade policy.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson and Jack Ewing

item.title: White House-Amazon Spat Culminates in Trump Calling Bezos ‘Very Nice’
item.description: The White House press secretary, Karoline Leavitt, attacked the retail giant over a report that suggested Amazon would highlight tariff-related price increases. Amazon said it was “not going to happen.”
item.dc:creator: Shawn McCreesh and Karen Weise

item.title: How Trump May Unintentionally Cut Carbon Emissions
item.description: Despite his administration’s lack of concern about climate change, a recession would give the atmosphere a break. At least in the short term.
item.dc:creator: Lydia DePillis

item.title: New Data Provide a Pre-Tariff Snapshot of a Stable but Slowing Labor Market
item.description: But the effects of the levies, which have created uncertainty for businesses, have not yet been fully felt.
item.dc:creator: Talmon Joseph Smith

item.title: Trump Administration Looks to Take Steps to Ease Pain From Car Tariffs
item.description: The planned concessions to give automakers more time to relocate production to the United States would still leave substantial tariffs on imported cars and car parts.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson and Jack Ewing

item.title: Trump’s 100-Day Economic Report Card
item.description: Market chaos and economic uncertainty has been a feature of the president’s first few months back in office. DealBook breaks down the milestones, and what to expect next.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Ross Sorkin, Ravi Mattu, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Edmund Lee

item.title: Why the Economic Disruption From Trump’s Tariff War Will Be Hard to Reverse
item.description: The president’s turnover of the economic order has unleashed changes that could prove lasting, because other countries will adjust.
item.dc:creator: Patricia Cohen

item.title: Howard Lutnick, Trump’s ‘Buoyant’ Trade Warrior, Flexes His Power Over Global Business
item.description: Howard Lutnick, the secretary of commerce, has become a go-to for major companies seeking relief from tariffs. But he’s not always friendly to their interests.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson
